topics.title: Medicare preventive services overview
topics.summary: Part B covers many preventive screenings and services. Costs are often $0 when criteria are met.
points: Part B covers many preventive and screening services when eligibility and frequency limits are met.
Costs are often $0 if your provider accepts assignment and you meet criteria.
Use Medicare's list to check what's covered and how often.
followups: Which screenings am I due for?
What does 'assignment' mean for costs?

topics.title: Schedule your Yearly Wellness Visit
topics.summary: Your annual wellness visit is free with Part B when your provider accepts assignment.
steps: Confirm you have Part B and that your provider accepts assignment.
Ask the office to schedule a 'Medicare Annual Wellness Visit', not a routine physical.
Bring your medicines list and complete any health risk assessments the office sends.
followups: What is the difference between a physical and a wellness visit?

topics.title: Get your 'Welcome to Medicare' visit
topics.summary: One-time preventive visit within 12 months of Part B enrollment.
steps: Check you are within 12 months of enrolling in Part B.
Call your provider and request the 'Welcome to Medicare' visit (IPPE).
Bring prior records and a list of providers, conditions, and medicines.
followups: What does the visit include?
What will I pay if my provider orders extra tests?

topics.title: Get the shingles (Shingrix) vaccine
topics.summary: Part D covers ACIP-recommended adult vaccines with no copay or deductible.
steps: Call your pharmacy to confirm they can bill your Part D plan for Shingrix.
Bring your Part D card or Medicare Advantage card to the pharmacy.
Schedule the second dose 2–6 months after the first dose.
followups: Is Shingrix covered with $0 cost to me?
Can I get this at my doctor's office instead of a pharmacy?

topics.title: Adult vaccines under Part D
topics.summary: Part D plans cover ACIP-recommended adult vaccines at $0 cost to you.
points: Part D covers ACIP-recommended adult vaccines like shingles, RSV, Tdap, and MMR.
Plans cannot charge a copay or apply a deductible for these recommended vaccines.
followups: Where should I get these shots billed to Part D?
How do I check if a specific vaccine is recommended by ACIP?

topics.title: Telehealth rules through and after Sep 30, 2025
topics.summary: Temporary broader telehealth access lasts through Sep 30, 2025. Most non-behavioral services narrow after that.
points: Through Sep 30, 2025, you can get many telehealth services from any location, including home.
Starting Oct 1, 2025, most non-behavioral telehealth services require you to be in a medical facility in a rural area.
Behavioral/mental health telehealth has permanent flexibilities (including audio-only in some cases).
followups: Will my Medicare Advantage plan keep broader telehealth access?
Can my clinic do audio-only visits for behavioral health?

topics.title: Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) coverage basics
topics.summary: Part A covers up to 100 days per benefit period when eligibility rules are met.
points: Part A covers up to 100 days of SNF care per benefit period if you meet eligibility.
A benefit period ends after 60 days without SNF or inpatient hospital care.
Costs vary by day ranges; long-term custodial care is not covered.
followups: What are my daily costs in 2025?
What if I need help with activities of daily living long term?

topics.title: Home health coverage basics
topics.summary: Medicare covers certain part-time or intermittent home health services if you are eligible.
points: Coverage can be under Part A and/or Part B depending on your situation.
Generally up to 8 hours per day, 28 hours per week (with limited exceptions).
You pay $0 for covered home health services; other costs may apply for supplies or DME.
followups: How do I find a Medicare-certified home health agency?
What are the eligibility requirements?

topics.title: Hospice coverage overview
topics.summary: Part A covers hospice for people with a terminal illness, with defined benefit periods.
points: Part A covers hospice after your provider certifies a terminal illness.
Coverage includes two 90-day periods followed by unlimited 60-day periods.
You may pay 5% for inpatient respite care; most other hospice services are $0.
followups: Can I change hospice providers?
What if I need care unrelated to my terminal illness?

topics.title: Ambulance services coverage
topics.summary: Part B covers medically necessary ambulance transport; some non-emergency rides may require prior authorization.
points: Part B covers ambulance when any other transportation could endanger your health.
Certain scheduled, non-emergency ambulance transports may require prior authorization.
If prior authorization is denied and you proceed, Medicare may deny the claim.
followups: What does my share of the cost look like under Part B?
Does my Medicare Advantage plan have different rules?

topics.title: Extra Help for drug costs (Part D LIS)
topics.summary: Extra Help lowers Part D costs for people with limited income and resources.
points: Extra Help can lower Part D premiums, deductibles, and copays, and removes the late-enrollment penalty while you have it.
Some people qualify automatically; others apply through Social Security.
followups: How do I apply for Extra Help?
What are the 2025 income and resource limits?

topics.title: Apply for Extra Help (Part D)
topics.summary: Use Social Security to apply online or by phone. You can apply before or after enrolling in Part D.
steps: Gather financial documents like bank statements and retirement account balances.
Apply online at SSA.gov for 'Part D Extra Help' or call Social Security.
If approved, your Part D costs may drop and late penalties are waived while you have Extra Help.
followups: Can I reapply if my income changes?
Do I need to already be in a Part D plan?

topics.title: Medicare Savings Programs (QMB, SLMB, QI, QDWI)
topics.summary: State-run programs can pay Part A/B premiums and sometimes deductibles/coinsurance for eligible people.
points: Programs include QMB, SLMB, QI, and QDWI; eligibility is based on income and resources.
If you qualify for SLMB or QI, you also get Extra Help for Part D; 2025 capped copays can apply for covered drugs.
followups: How do I apply in my state?
What are the 2025 limits for my household size?

topics.title: Part D Prescription Payment Plan (2025)
topics.summary: Option to spread out-of-pocket drug costs across the calendar year starting in 2025.
points: The payment plan spreads your out-of-pocket Part D costs across the year.
It does not lower drug prices; it changes when you pay.
followups: How do I enroll or opt out mid-year?
Does this affect my Extra Help eligibility?
